resources.string: For thousands of years many Aboriginal people have relied on the Murray River for resources. Many scarred trees (canoes crafted from River Red gums), banks of river rich with sites including rock art, shields and other artefacts.

55 km south of Turkey Creek rock paintings are found in some of the shelters, caves and gorges.. Motifs being ancestral beings from the Dreamtime, crocodiles, fish and stencils of children\'s hands. Few are available for public viewing.
Aboriginal people have been fishing and collecting shellfish on Fraser Island for more than a thousand years and many of their middens can be seen along the east coast."

This Red Hands Cave site is one of the best examples of Aboriginal art in the Blue Mountains National Park. The cave is a gallery of fine hand stencils and hand prints, created between 500 and 1600 years ago. Many of the stencils and prints overlap, making it difficult to see how many hands there are. Stencils are also a sign of respect for Country, and have a deep spiritual connection with the land. To make the stencils, Aboriginal people placed one hand against the cave wall and blew a mixture of ochre and water from their mouths. When the hand was removed, a stencilled outline was left behind. At other times, people covered their hands with ochre and placed them on the wall, leaving an imprint.
Is the oldest known Aboriginal site in the ACT (Ngunnawal people).
Open to the public are rockshelters with rock art such as Balancing Rock.
One of the most important Aboriginal art sites in Tasmania. Geometric motiffs cover nearly every inch of rock. Numerous deeply sculpted circles and other motiffs.
Large Aboriginal Stone Quarry sites around Innamincka.
About 40 Aboriginal Sites, hand stencils, stone artefacts and stone arrangements.

Uluru, the most distinctive symbol of the Australian landscape. The park consists of two outstanding features- Uluru and the dramatic rock domes of Kata Tjuta( the Mount Olga group). Aboriginal owners of the rock are the Pitjantjatjara and Yankunytjatjara people. The caves around the base of Uluru are adorned with hundreds of rock paintings.
